questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents with complaints of severe itching in both his hands for the last 2 weeks. He reports that the itching is significantly worse at night and disturbs his sleep. His hands show lesions characteristic of scabies. Which body site is usually not affected by this condition?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Face

 

Explanation:

The likely diagnosis of this case is scabies, a parasitic infection of the skin caused by Sarcoptes scabiei (itch mite).

Mode of spread: Scabies are highly contagious, and transmission is by skin-to-skin contact and fomites. Risk factors include poor personal hygiene.

Clinical manifestation:

  • The characteristic sign of scabies is the presence of burrows, Are thin, grayish-white or skin-colored, linear or wavy lines found in areas like the webbing between fingers, wrists, elbows, armpits, waistline, buttocks, genital area, and ankles, causing intense itching, especially at night.

  • Examination typically reveals excoriated papules, typically over the web spaces of the fingers (as shown in the image).

Other areas of the body that must be examined for lesions include:

  1. The medial aspect of the wrist

  2. The medial aspect of the forearm

  3. Umbilicus (Option D)

  4. Axilla (Option B)

  5. Nipple

  6. Genitalia/ groin (Option C) - burrows (wavy, grey tunnels)

This distribution is called the circle of Hebra.

The face is typically spared, due to high amounts of sebum in the facial skin but  pre pubecent children lack sebaceous glands and hence their faces can be affected

Circle of Hebra demonstrating the typical location of scabies lesions:

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is diagnosed with scabies after presenting with severe itching lesions, predominantly over his wrists and hands. What is the first-line treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 5% Permethrin

 

Explanation:

  • 5% Permethrin is the drug of choice for scabies. It is given in addition to general measures:
    • Anti-histamines for pruritus
    • Wash clothes, and bedding with hot water
    • Examine and treat family members
  • MOA: Blocks sodium channels of the itch mite, causing paralysis.
  • Application: Apply below the neck for 8-12 hours at a time (overnight); it is typically applied twice, one week apart.
  • It is safe and can be used in all patients older than 2 months.
  • 1% Permethrinis used for pediculosis

 

GBHC (option B): An older chloride-channel blocker that is rarely used. It is also not safe in pregnancy, in those with neurologic disorders, and in children.


Precipitated sulfur (option C): While safe and effective, this is not the first choice, as its odour can make it unpleasant to use, But can be used in infants <2 months old.


Ivermectin (option D): Given orally (200mc/kg—two doses). It is typically reserved for patients with scabies who do not respond to permethrin, atypical scabies, and those who cannot comply with or tolerate topical alternatives.

Briefly, other drugs include- Crotamiton (not safe in children), Malathion, Benzyl Benzoate, and Lindane (not safe in children, pregnancy).

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with lymphoma on chemotherapy presents with large, crusted plaques over her entire torso, arm, and legs. She reports minimal itching. What is the optimal treatment regimen for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ivermectin + Permethrin

 

Explanation:

This patient likely has crusted scabies or Norwegian scabies (NS).

This is a severe form of scabies due to massive infestation of the itch mite. Risk factors include:

  1. Immunocompromise (HIV, malignancy, etc)
  2. Old age
  3. Neurologic disease

NS is characterized by large, hyperkeratotic plaques that may cover up to 90% of the body's surface. Due to diminished immunity, pruritus is typically absent, contributing to the accumulation of crusts. These crusts can contain millions of mites and their eggs.

Treatment involves both oral ivermectin and topical permethrin. Additionally, a keratolytic agent may be used to help the penetration of permethrin.


Topical steroids (Option D): Topical steroids are the treatment of choice for nodular scabies, a special form of scabies caused by a hypersensitivity response to the mites. The lesions are typically pruritic, with firm nodules/ papules over the axilla and groin.

Nodules in the axilla of a patient with nodular scabies

questions.text: A 6-month-old girl is brought by her parents for evaluation of a rash. On examination, she appears uncomfortable, and there are multiple small red papules on her face, palms, and soles. Multiple small burrows are also seen. Microscopy of skin scrapings is shown below. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sarcoptes scabiei

 

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario describes infantile scabies. Infantile scabies are similar to adult scabies, except that there is more extensive involvement, including the face, palms, and soles.
  • Examination reveals erythematous papules with burrows. Lesions may even be vesicular or bullous due to greater inflammatory response in children.
  • Skin scraping and microscopic examination of the epidermis from the affected sites establish the diagnosis of scabies.
  • KOH may be used to dissolve keratin debris.
  • Microscopic evaluation will reveal mites, eggs, and feces.

Mite with eggs

 

Phthirus pubis (Option A) – Causes pubic lice (crab louse infestation), primarily affecting pubic hair, not associated with burrows or extensive infantile involvement.


C. Trichophyton (Option C) – A dermatophyte fungus responsible for tinea infections (e.g., ringworm), which presents with scaly patches rather than burrows or vesicles.


Staphylococcus aureus (Option D) – Can cause impetigo and bullous skin infections but does not produce burrows, mites, or microscopic eggs in skin scrapings.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old girl presents with complaints of an itchy scalp for the last few days. Local inspection reveals mild crusting in areas of the scalp, with multiple white nits along the hair shafts. What is the causative organism?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pediculus humanus capitis

 

Explanation:

 

Pediculosis capitis

Pediculosis corporis

Pediculosis pubis

Spread

Skin-to-skin contact/ fomites

Skin-to-skin contact/ fomites

Skin-to-skin contact sexually transmitted

Causative agent

Head louse (Pediculus humanus capitis) (Option D)

Body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis) (Option A)

Pubic louse (pthris pubis) (Option B)

Classical scenario

School-going children

(girls - long hair)

Destitute and homeless

-

Presentation, clinical features

Itching of the scalp.

Multiple lice or nits (empty eggs of the lice)

May be crusting, secondary folliculitis secondary to scratching.

May have regional lymphadenopathy.

Morbus Errorum (body lice infestation) is characterized by excoriated itchy papules over the body and the presence of nits in the folds of clothes.

Itchy papules in the groin and genital region.

 

‘Macula cerulea’ is a bluish dot over the affected area caused by blood extravasation secondary to anticoagulants in the louse’s saliva.

Treatment

1% permethrin

1% permethrin

1% permethrin

Pediculus humanus

 

Pubic louse

 

Sarcoptes scabiei (Option C) causes scabies, which classically presents with itchy papules over the webbed spaces of the fingers. The face and scalp are typically spared.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old female presents with an itchy lesion as shown below. She reports that it started as a small, red, itchy spot, then progressed over the next few days to its current form. She also reveals a recent beach holiday. What is the causative organism?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ancylostoma caninum

 

Explanation:

  • The given case scenario describes cutaneous larva migrans.
  • This is caused by animal hookworm larvae (Ancylostoma braziliensis/ caninum) and typically occurs due to walking barefoot on contaminated sand or soil.
  • It classically begins with a pruritic, erythematous papule at the site of penetration, followed by intensely pruritic, serpiginous, reddish-brown skin tracks, along the path of migration of the larvae. These develop slowly over days (1-2 cm/day)
  • The larvae cannot penetrate beyond the dermis, so systemic manifestations are uncommon.
  • Treatment involves oral ivermectin.

 

Loa loa (Option A) is the African eye worm. It causes Calabar swellings, painless, transient swellings over the eyelid.

 

Strongyloides stercoralis (Option C) causes larva currens by its intradermal migration. While similar to cutaneous larva migrans, it is distinguished by more rapid migration within the skin (5-15 cm/hour), intense urticaria surrounding the path of migration, and potential perianal involvement.


Ascaris lumbricoides (Option D) causes ascariasis with larvae migrating through the bloodstream to the lungs and intestines, causing primarily gastrointestinal and respiratory symptoms. Unlike hookworms, Ascaris larvae do not migrate within the skin and thus do not cause cutaneous larva migrans.

questions.text:
As shown in the figure, a 10-year-old boy presents with a painless swelling over his left lower eyelid. He reports visiting the Amazon forest on vacation with his family recently. If left untreated, which of the following is not a long-term risk?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sleeping sickness

 

Explanation:

American trypanosomiasis:

The given image shows Romana's sign, i.e., a swollen nodule or ‘chagoma’ at the site of infection, most commonly over the eyelids or near the mouth. This is an early sign of Trypanosoma cruzei infection, which is endemic to South America and is therefore called American trypanosomiasis.

Trypanosoma cruzei is transmitted via the bite of the Reduviid bug, or kissing bug (named so because the bite is painless).

Early symptoms are non-specific and include fever, lymphadenopathy, and the Romana sign.

If untreated, it can lead to Chaga’s disease, the manifestations of which include

  1. Dilated cardiomyopathy - heart failure (option B), arrhythmias, sudden cardiac death.
  2. Megaesophagus and megacolon (options C and D) - due to autonomic nerve destruction.

Diagnosis of acute disease is by demonstration of T cruzi trypomastigote on blood smears.

Treatment of acute disease involves Nifurtimox or Benznidazole.
Chaga’s disease is incurable and requires supportive care as appropriate.

 

Sleeping sickness:

  • This is caused by T. brucei (rhodesiense or gambiense). It is endemic to rural Africa and is transmitted by the tse tse fly. It is also known as African trypanosomiasis.
  • Early infection is non-specific, with fever, cervical lymphadenopathy (Winterbottom’s sign: posterior cervical triangle lymphadenopathy), Kerandl sign (delayed pain after a sharp blow or squeeze to soft tissue) and arthralgia, which lasts for varying lengths of time.
  • Late infection is characterized by neuropsychiatric manifestations, with sleep-wake cycle disturbance prominent.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male soldier who had recently been deployed to Iraq presents with a mildly itchy, raised rash on his neck. He has no other systemic complaints. Examination revealed a painless plaque with ulceration and overlying crusting associated with  tender posterior lymphadenopathy. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Leishmania major

 

Explanation:

  • This case describes Old World Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (CL) in a soldier recently deployed to Iraq, a region endemic for Leishmania major. The clinical features (painless ulcerated plaque with crusting and lymphadenopathy) are classic for cutaneous leishmaniasis.

  • Leishmaniasis is a vector-borne disease caused by protozoa of the genus Leishmania, transmitted by female sand flies (Phlebotomus in the Old World).

  • The clinical spectrum ranges from cutaneous ulcers to systemic multiorgan disease (visceral leishmaniasis).

Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (CL):

Type Region Species Clinical Features
Old World CL Middle East, Africa, Asia L. major, L. tropica Painless papule → nodule/plaque → ulcer, often with crusting and raised volcano-like margins
New World CL Central and South America L. mexicana, L. braziliensis Similar lesions; L. mexicana causes Chiclero's ulcer (chronic ulcers on the ear due to multiple bites)

 

New World CL: The ulcer may be covered with thick white-yellow fibrinous material. ‘Chiclero’s ulcer’ - multiple, small, chronic ulcers on the ear, due to multiple sandfly bites.

  

Mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis (ML):

  • Caused by L. braziliensis (Option B).

  • Involves mucosal destruction of the nasal septum, mouth, and throat.

  • Features include nasal congestion, bleeding, pain, and eventual disfigurement.

 

Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala-azar):

  • Caused by Leishmania donovani (Option D).

  • Presents with fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia.

  • No cutaneous lesions are typical.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female who recently migrated from Bihar presents for evaluation of a new rash. Her history is significant for low-grade fever and fatigue over the last few months. She reports receiving some treatment at the local government hospital, but cannot recount any more details. Examination reveals hundreds of hypopigmented macules over her back and arms. She also has palpable splenomegaly. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis

 

Explanation:

  • This patient likely has post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis due to inadequately treated visceral leishmaniasis (VL).
  • VL is transmitted by sandflies and is caused by L. donovani or L. infantum.
  • Splenomegaly is characteristically massive.
  • It is characterized by multiple hypopigmented macules, typically on the trunk. These may progress to papules/ nodules.
  • Lesions may resemble those of lepromatous leprosy (Option C), but there are no associated sensorineural changes.
  • A definitive diagnosis of VL requires the demonstration of Leishmania by smear or culture, typically using a bone marrow sample. PKDL may be diagnosed via PCR of macular scrapings.
  • Treatment of VL involves liposomal Amphotericin B, while PKDL may be managed with Oral Miltefosin.

Cutaneous leishmaniasis (Option B) is typically characterized by a pink papule that ultimately forms an indurated ulcer. There may be associated eschar (Old World) or yellow fibrin coverage (New World).


Pityriasis versicolor (Option D) is a cutaneous fungal infection that may also present with multiple hypopigmented macules. However, it typically lacks systemic complaints, as seen in this patient.
